Extract of letter to the Editor Of the American


Farmer, from distinguished officer Of the U.


States Navy, dated Callao Roads, June ~, 1922.


81 am of opinion that the wealth Of these South
American states is greatly overrated. They have
mines to be sure, but they neither are nor can be-
worked to much profit; for both individuals and
companies have failed who have OF late attempted
it; and the other products are very limited Chilli
and Peru by many degrees the poorest countries
I have seen, and can there be stronger evil
dence of this truth than that with small debt, and
scarcely any military force, their treasures are al
ways elnpty-thcr expenditure though but little
more than 81, 100000, yet exceeding their income.
81 would contribute, at almost any trouble, to any
Improvement in the breed of horses in country;
but am confident that there is not horse or marc
in Chill or Peru that would sell for one hundred do-
lars. | have not seen one which would, if in the
United States, bring sixty dollars. have brought
| a saddle horse from Mendoza, one OF the handsoms
that have here, and gave ten douboons tor
him. which is the highest price going; but really i'll
MARYLAND he would not sell for sixty dollars; and
this horse has been brought over the Corderas to
Valparaiso, 400 miles, and from thence here by wa.
ter, from 12 TO Is days sail.


You certainly know that the horses, cattle, sliee,s
and hogs, of Spanish America, were all brought froru
Spain and the only port Of expectation for these
animals was Caniz, the Southern extremity of An
dalusa. Consequently the animals Of that provinca
have, do aver, much degenerated from their pro-
genitors i'll form and size No one, who has been
in Andausia would be at loss to perceive that the
above mentioned animals have had their origin there3
the form. colour and spirit is very much the same,
particularly the latter, which is remarkable, and il
equally perceptible in the wild horses of Louisiana
and the state Of Mississippi, aud the western Flor
Il jua.S
THE HORSES or SOUTH AMERICA.

icuties. The fourth section of the Canal, through
st. Georges mill pond about three miles, is also
filled with water and navgable The fifth section,
comprising the deep cut, said TO be the most stupen
dous instance of canal excavation in the world, is in
great degree completed up to the Summit Bridge,
to which point boats from the Delaware SAIL


The sides ofthis portion of the canal are to be wal


led with thick masonry to the height Of twelve feet
and for distance, including both banks, of five or
six miles. Much Of this gigantic work is done, and


the masons are engaged IN completing it rapidly as
possible. The remaining sections, TO the Chesa-
peake, have been for some time finished, and are


ready for the admission of water the rest


OF the work will permit il. The four locks are
| completed, and the bridges are in use; that at the
| summit is noble structure--it spans gulf nearly
three hundred feet wide and hundred feet deep,


presenting from the road way view along the canal
east and west for several miles, II is believed that
the western division of the work will be completed


early in the spring. and that the whole will be done
by the next summer.
FRIDAY, .1'orember so, 1927.

sHe who has Trade has an Estate, ,"--ETanklas.


This is one of the many correct and iudicious say
ings of that truly great man, whose judgement of
mankind was formed by experience and whose wri-
tings are held up to the admiration of the world.
No better maxims ar. to be found, or rules which.
if attended to, will eventually lead the unfortunate
to repair their losses, overcome difficulties and re
gain lost ground. The above is worthy of deep
reflection. and speaks volumes Of itself. speaks
language that is easily understood, and many are
they who will really subscribe to its truth, who are
now labourngin difficulty and distress, to procure
the hard earned pittance for daily bread.


Happy would it be (and how much misery avoid
ed) if more of our youth were properly placed In
situations congenial to their minds and genius.
wherein they could learn the art of mechanic
In this respect much judgment ought to be exercls,
ed that wrong turn be not given TO the mind, but
that due regard be had to the natural bent Of gen.
us. To thwart this is to destroy the pride and
ambition. from which results disahecton and often
ruin. Whatever the feelings of a parent may he
for his child, his own experience will teach him the
propriety Of his sons having calling that enables
him to support not only himself, but perhaps taml
| ly. I have seen the young man born to an af1uent
fortune, who was early apprenticed to respec-
table and scientific mechanic to learn what is gene
rally termed trade. Althoughthere was appar-
ent need of such step-as the father was an indie
dendent man--stilI the old gentleman conceived
that it was necessary, and often made the observa
tion, s'that he who has trade has an estate" The
young man duly served his time. and became com
plete master of his trade and this son had the happi
ness to contribute to the and support of his tru
lv respectable parent in his old age (who had lost
through misfortune his immense property,) and while
performing this pleasing sacred duty. his talents
and industry raised him to an enylabe situation in
| life.
LEARN A TRADE.
"He who has Trade has an Estate, ,"--Frankli7a.

From, the New York Epcning Gazette.


We had an opportunity of hearing Mr.. Webster
sum up on Saturday last in the Astor case. His
speech was masterly display of argumentative
skill: it was evidently the production of a mind
we'll trained in logical discipline. and accustomed to
the tactics of forensic warfare. This however. though
the most essential qualification of the advocate can
not without the aid of the other qualities, make an
individual capable of the highest eminencein his pro-
fession. and those qualities Mr.. Webster either wants
or despises in his efforts at the bar-Whe sound
reasoning and profound legal knowledge should be
the prominent objects of the candidate for profess
sional fame, yet we no reason why he should
neglect or contemn those graces of speech and ex-
cursions of the fancy, which constitute the oraori
cal art. From Mr.. Webster's displays in the House
of Representative which have been published. we
were inclined to think that he was more even of a
rhetorcian than reasoner; though we could not fail
to observe happy combination Of the qualities of
both. On this account. we felt some dsappoint-
ment on Saturday. still we considered Mr.. Web
ser's speech masterly and beautiful piece of reas-
oning. calculated to inspire the hearer with respect
and to illustrate the subject in lucid and succinct
manner, Of which, to the observer, it SEEM
ed scarcely susceptible.
MR.. WEBSTER.
Iron, the New York Epening Gazef

PoTAToEs.-We recommend, from experience
the following directions for gathering and preserving
potatoes, to all who desire to have them good.
There is another plan however, which might be
practised upon a small scale, to have. few prime
for family in the spring, and that is not to
gather the potatoes in the fall but to let them re-
main in the ground during the winter If the patch
he not flooded with water and the potatoes have
been planted moderate depth, (and deep planting
is always found to produce the sweetest potatoes,
few inches additional earth. or an equivalent OF
litter spread the rows, will protect them from
frost. Then take them up early in the spring, be-
fore vegetation commences, and they will be found
to possess. in an eminent degree, the sweet fresh
ness Of new potatoes.
From the Pennsylvania Gazette.

The Paris Constitutional preludes crltique Oh
the French translation Of Knickerbocker,' as foi4
lows: " Rallery is exiled from the literary world
we have given up joking. Cervantes Rabelais,
Swift, Sterne, lie Sage, and more than all Votaires
have exhausted irony humanity no longer laughs
she bewails her miseries and her fobles. There is
cry Of universal desoation, or rather Of rcvolts
against remediable evils, ant, from which we might
easily be spared. In the accession Of this grave
melancholy, there is also little conventional sad.
ness, habitude which forms the character Of tho
age.


The transatlantic regions are better situated for
making jokes at the world, and irony has found an
asylum there. at least if one may judge from thia
:. History Of New York." the best work Of the best
writer that the new world has as vet produced.


This jesting book, in which the sarcasm mounts
up to the creation of the world. in which under the
pretext of writing the history of Dutch colony. the
author parodies not only the great yanites but also
with scarcely any distinction. all human institutions.
is work more singular than philosophc.


We take it very kindly Of the author that he has
inundated on the same altar all the theposts WIN
have built up the world in their own way Herodo-
tus and his patriarchal romancpgs modern hisori-
ans and their mnutely prolix details, the Scottish
pride of upstarts, who are absolutely determined to
be the descendants of Theseus, OF Hector, or of
Melchisedec Still one would wish that iudicious
dissertation on ancient civilization should not lead
the author to a satire of modern civilization, and
that man who bears the name of Washington
should not use his endeavors to eneeble the esteem
in which Europe holds the country Of Washington
and Franklin.


Lord Byron set high value upon this work on
account of its animated satire upon the manners
and absurdties of of petty democracles this kind
of irony is agreeable to oarisocratic tastes. of which
his genius was never entirely divested. In this re-
spec MIR. Irving is less excusable. and may be just
ly reproached with having too often directed his
sarcasms against virtues, which however simple,
plain, and somewhat odd. are, nevertheless, always
worthy of respect, and which shauld never have
been quzzcd By an ,4mcricaa pen.
WASHINGTON IRVING.

Gathering and preserving potatoes.


Extracted from the Transactions Of the Society
OF Arts in London.


The usual mode at present practising for endeav-
curing to preserve potatoes is to leave them alter
digging, exposed 10 sun and air to dry. This ex-
posure generally causes them to haye bitter taste;
and may be remarked, that potatoes are never SO
sweet to the palate as when cooked Immediately al
ter digging. find that when potatoes are lett IN
large heaps pits in the ground, that fermentation
takes place which destroys the sweetest favour OF
the potatoes. In order to prevent that fermentation
and to preserve them from losing the original hne
and pleasant favour, my plan is, (and which expe-
rence proves to me to have the desired edecD'to
have them packed in casks as they are digging from
the ground and to have the casks when the potatoes
are piled in them, filled up with sand or earth, TAX
ing care that it is done as speedily possible and
that all spaces in the cask of potatoes are Sled up
with earth or sand the cask thus packed holds Az
many potatoes as it would were no earth or sand
used and as the air is totally excluded it cannot act
on the potatoes, and consequently no Fermentation
can take place.
yTO. 81.
Gathering and preserving potatoes.

One Willy Wright who kept store,
But nothing kept therein,
Save earthen jugs and some few kegs
of whiskey, ale and gin,-
Grew sick, and often would exclaim,
Oh how my heart does burn!
And ev'ry week he poor man lived
lie had peakiy turn.
NV when they saw him thus decline,
Some said that death must come;
Some wondered what his all could be,
Some sad his ale was rum.
htlast the very cause was known


Of every pang he felt
Remote, at one end of the town,


Miss Martha Townsend dwclt;
portly love-resising dame,


Contemptuous, proud and haughty;
But yet, though "fat and forty" too,
She was not two and-forty.
And Willy long had sought and sighd
To gain this pretty maid
'Ihave no trade said he, $50 sure.
My love cant be be.tray'd'
To Martha then he trembling went,
And said, MY dear, 'tis true,
Though have nothing in my store,
Ive love in store foryou.
And if thou wilt thou may'st become
But here his tongue was tied;
And though she ufited yet she said
She mere would be his bride.
Then TURNING Willy out of doors,
Said she, Go, so along;
Illate the man who's always Wright,
Yet always doing wrong.'
Il leave you them said he, farewell
OF peace Pm now bereft--
If am always Wright and wrong,


You must be right, and left ,
So then he closed his little store,


Shut up each door and blind,
And settled his accounts and died,


And left Ho will belind II
LOVE.SICk WILLY.
One Willy Wright, who kent store

I. Resolved, That this Society regard the intem-
perate use of spirtnous liquors as the most gene
raj and the most deadly evil which ailcts our land
and that, in our opinion, it now becomes the solemn
duty of all the temperate and viruous part of our
community to make united, RATIONAL vigorous and
persevering effort to arrest its progress.


Q. RESOLVED, That in the opinion OF this Society,
to eloc drunkard, either to make laws, or, to ex-
ecue them, when made, s, virtually, not only to
legahze but to honor crime-to break down the bar
rier which Reason, Truth and Scripture have fixed
between virtue and vice--and to lay the axe at the
very root Of the Tree Of Liberty.


3. Resolved, That in the estimation Of this SocIe-
ty, the employment of drunken servant-a drum
ken mechanc--a drunken schoolmaster or an in
temperate physician, without necessity. and merely
because such may be obtained, upon cheaper terms
than such as are sober and Industrious, is to crafty
avarice at the expense of moral principles to ex-
ercse and indulge narrow, selfish disposition, in
the place of that heaven-horn benevolence which
consults the good ofthe 70holc community.


A. Resolved, That, we esteem it good rule and
worthy Of universal observance. for every minister,
when called to preach funeral sermon to let it be
distinctly understood. as condition. that no splrtu-
Gus liquor be used on the occasion.


5. ResolUcd That il be recommended to the fe-
male part of the community to dscountenance and
| frown from their social circles all young men who
are frequently known to be in state of intoxlca-


ton, and to look aYitt suspicion upon such as tona
of strong drink.


6. Resolyed. That we view, with the deepest re-
Gret, the erroneous conduct of those parents who
train up their children to the regular, habtuaI uee
of strong drink The wisest OF men hath said !;
g Train up child in the way he should go, and when
he is old he will not depart from it." IT tins be
true as general rule when children are trained 10
sobriety, industry and piety how much more may
those parents who train up their children, by pre-
cept and example, to believe, that the habtual use
of strong drink s essential to their health and COM
fort expect that the habit uiH become second ma
t,.re that the chains put on, in infancy, and worn
with ease and without suspicion, to manhood VIII,
in old age if not before, bind the victims to iniamy
and death.
RI T. Resolved, That we recommend to all gonng
ministers, who desire that their instructions and
warnings against the sin of drunkenness may have
the desired effect, to abstain altogether from the
use of spurious liquors.


Chcsnpeoke and Delauarc Canul.--Thc Phi'adel-
uhia National Gazette furnishes the following no.
tice of the present condition of this Canal The
three sections through the marshes from the Deia-
ware river to ST. Georges about four miles in length.
are filled with water nearly as high MS the common
high water of the river, and an active navigation
along it in sloops and scows for the purposes of the
Canal is carried on ; dredging machine is employ
ed in excavating such parts as arc not to the full
depth of ten feet the towing path embankment
Through the marsh has ceased to sink, and appears
TO stand perfectly firm; the south guard bank, OF
which the sinking was so rapid and extensive, and
, 1.-THE extra expense so great, will be completed it is

full articles.headline: THE HORSES or SOUTH AMERICA.
full articles.article:
Extract of letter to the Editor Of the American


Farmer, from distinguished officer Of the U.


States Navy, dated Callao Roads, June ~, 1922.


81 am of opinion that the wealth Of these South
American states is greatly overrated. They have
mines to be sure, but they neither are nor can be-
worked to much profit; for both individuals and
companies have failed who have OF late attempted
it; and the other products are very limited Chilli
and Peru by many degrees the poorest countries
I have seen, and can there be stronger evil
dence of this truth than that with small debt, and
scarcely any military force, their treasures are al
ways elnpty-thcr expenditure though but little
more than 81, 100000, yet exceeding their income.
81 would contribute, at almost any trouble, to any
Improvement in the breed of horses in country;
but am confident that there is not horse or marc
in Chill or Peru that would sell for one hundred do-
lars. | have not seen one which would, if in the
United States, bring sixty dollars. have brought
| a saddle horse from Mendoza, one OF the handsoms
that have here, and gave ten douboons tor
him. which is the highest price going; but really i'll
MARYLAND he would not sell for sixty dollars; and
this horse has been brought over the Corderas to
Valparaiso, 400 miles, and from thence here by wa.
ter, from 12 TO Is days sail.


You certainly know that the horses, cattle, sliee,s
and hogs, of Spanish America, were all brought froru
Spain and the only port Of expectation for these
animals was Caniz, the Southern extremity of An
dalusa. Consequently the animals Of that provinca
have, do aver, much degenerated from their pro-
genitors i'll form and size No one, who has been
in Andausia would be at loss to perceive that the
above mentioned animals have had their origin there3
the form. colour and spirit is very much the same,
particularly the latter, which is remarkable, and il
equally perceptible in the wild horses of Louisiana

full articles.headline:
LEARN A TRADE.

"He who has Trade has an Estate, ,"--Frankli7a.
full articles.article:
sHe who has Trade has an Estate, ,"--ETanklas.


This is one of the many correct and iudicious say
ings of that truly great man, whose judgement of
mankind was formed by experience and whose wri-
tings are held up to the admiration of the world.
No better maxims ar. to be found, or rules which.
if attended to, will eventually lead the unfortunate
to repair their losses, overcome difficulties and re
gain lost ground. The above is worthy of deep
reflection. and speaks volumes Of itself. speaks
language that is easily understood, and many are
they who will really subscribe to its truth, who are
now labourngin difficulty and distress, to procure
the hard earned pittance for daily bread.


Happy would it be (and how much misery avoid
ed) if more of our youth were properly placed In
situations congenial to their minds and genius.
wherein they could learn the art of mechanic
In this respect much judgment ought to be exercls,
ed that wrong turn be not given TO the mind, but
that due regard be had to the natural bent Of gen.
us. To thwart this is to destroy the pride and
ambition. from which results disahecton and often
ruin. Whatever the feelings of a parent may he
for his child, his own experience will teach him the
propriety Of his sons having calling that enables
him to support not only himself, but perhaps taml
| ly. I have seen the young man born to an af1uent
fortune, who was early apprenticed to respec-
table and scientific mechanic to learn what is gene
rally termed trade. Althoughthere was appar-
ent need of such step-as the father was an indie
dendent man--stilI the old gentleman conceived
that it was necessary, and often made the observa
tion, s'that he who has trade has an estate" The
young man duly served his time. and became com
plete master of his trade and this son had the happi
ness to contribute to the and support of his tru
lv respectable parent in his old age (who had lost
through misfortune his immense property,) and while
performing this pleasing sacred duty. his talents
and industry raised him to an enylabe situation in
| life.

full articles.headline: MR.. WEBSTER.
full articles.article:
From, the New York Epcning Gazette.


We had an opportunity of hearing Mr.. Webster
sum up on Saturday last in the Astor case. His
speech was masterly display of argumentative
skill: it was evidently the production of a mind
we'll trained in logical discipline. and accustomed to
the tactics of forensic warfare. This however. though
the most essential qualification of the advocate can
not without the aid of the other qualities, make an
individual capable of the highest eminencein his pro-
fession. and those qualities Mr.. Webster either wants
or despises in his efforts at the bar-Whe sound
reasoning and profound legal knowledge should be
the prominent objects of the candidate for profess
sional fame, yet we no reason why he should
neglect or contemn those graces of speech and ex-
cursions of the fancy, which constitute the oraori
cal art. From Mr.. Webster's displays in the House
of Representative which have been published. we
were inclined to think that he was more even of a
rhetorcian than reasoner; though we could not fail
to observe happy combination Of the qualities of
both. On this account. we felt some dsappoint-
ment on Saturday. still we considered Mr.. Web
ser's speech masterly and beautiful piece of reas-
oning. calculated to inspire the hearer with respect
and to illustrate the subject in lucid and succinct
manner, Of which, to the observer, it SEEM
ed scarcely susceptible.

full articles.headline: From the Pennsylvania Gazette.
full articles.article:
PoTAToEs.-We recommend, from experience
the following directions for gathering and preserving
potatoes, to all who desire to have them good.
There is another plan however, which might be
practised upon a small scale, to have. few prime
for family in the spring, and that is not to
gather the potatoes in the fall but to let them re-
main in the ground during the winter If the patch
he not flooded with water and the potatoes have
been planted moderate depth, (and deep planting
is always found to produce the sweetest potatoes,
few inches additional earth. or an equivalent OF
litter spread the rows, will protect them from
frost. Then take them up early in the spring, be-
fore vegetation commences, and they will be found
to possess. in an eminent degree, the sweet fresh
ness Of new potatoes.

is work more singular than philosophc.


We take it very kindly Of the author that he has
inundated on the same altar all the theposts WIN
have built up the world in their own way Herodo-
tus and his patriarchal romancpgs modern hisori-
ans and their mnutely prolix details, the Scottish
pride of upstarts, who are absolutely determined to
be the descendants of Theseus, OF Hector, or of
Melchisedec Still one would wish that iudicious
dissertation on ancient civilization should not lead
the author to a satire of modern civilization, and
that man who bears the name of Washington
should not use his endeavors to eneeble the esteem
in which Europe holds the country Of Washington
and Franklin.


Lord Byron set high value upon this work on
account of its animated satire upon the manners
and absurdties of of petty democracles this kind
of irony is agreeable to oarisocratic tastes. of which
his genius was never entirely divested. In this re-
spec MIR. Irving is less excusable. and may be just
ly reproached with having too often directed his
sarcasms against virtues, which however simple,
plain, and somewhat odd. are, nevertheless, always
worthy of respect, and which shauld never have
been quzzcd By an ,4mcricaa pen.

full articles.headline:
yTO. 81.


Gathering and preserving potatoes.
full articles.article:
Gathering and preserving potatoes.


Extracted from the Transactions Of the Society
OF Arts in London.


The usual mode at present practising for endeav-
curing to preserve potatoes is to leave them alter
digging, exposed 10 sun and air to dry. This ex-
posure generally causes them to haye bitter taste;
and may be remarked, that potatoes are never SO
sweet to the palate as when cooked Immediately al
ter digging. find that when potatoes are lett IN
large heaps pits in the ground, that fermentation
takes place which destroys the sweetest favour OF
the potatoes. In order to prevent that fermentation
and to preserve them from losing the original hne
and pleasant favour, my plan is, (and which expe-
rence proves to me to have the desired edecD'to
have them packed in casks as they are digging from
the ground and to have the casks when the potatoes
are piled in them, filled up with sand or earth, TAX
ing care that it is done as speedily possible and
that all spaces in the cask of potatoes are Sled up
with earth or sand the cask thus packed holds Az
many potatoes as it would were no earth or sand
used and as the air is totally excluded it cannot act
on the potatoes, and consequently no Fermentation
can take place.

full articles.headline:
LOVE.SICk WILLY.

One Willy Wright, who kent store
full articles.article:
One Willy Wright who kept store,
But nothing kept therein,
Save earthen jugs and some few kegs
of whiskey, ale and gin,-
Grew sick, and often would exclaim,
Oh how my heart does burn!
And ev'ry week he poor man lived
lie had peakiy turn.
NV when they saw him thus decline,
Some said that death must come;
Some wondered what his all could be,
Some sad his ale was rum.
htlast the very cause was known


Of every pang he felt
Remote, at one end of the town,


Miss Martha Townsend dwclt;
portly love-resising dame,


Contemptuous, proud and haughty;
But yet, though "fat and forty" too,
She was not two and-forty.
And Willy long had sought and sighd
To gain this pretty maid
'Ihave no trade said he, $50 sure.
My love cant be be.tray'd'
To Martha then he trembling went,
And said, MY dear, 'tis true,
Though have nothing in my store,
Ive love in store foryou.
And if thou wilt thou may'st become
But here his tongue was tied;
And though she ufited yet she said
She mere would be his bride.
Then TURNING Willy out of doors,
Said she, Go, so along;
Illate the man who's always Wright,
Yet always doing wrong.'
Il leave you them said he, farewell
OF peace Pm now bereft--
If am always Wright and wrong,


You must be right, and left ,
So then he closed his little store,


Shut up each door and blind,
And settled his accounts and died,


And left Ho will belind II

full articles.headline:
HEM

VIRGINIA SOCIETY FOR THE PROMOTION


OF TEMPERANCE.
full articles.article:
HeSofhf10nS Gdopte6 al MeaT meeunS-


I. Resolved, That this Society regard the intem-
perate use of spirtnous liquors as the most gene
raj and the most deadly evil which ailcts our land
and that, in our opinion, it now becomes the solemn
duty of all the temperate and viruous part of our
community to make united, RATIONAL vigorous and
persevering effort to arrest its progress.


Q. RESOLVED, That in the opinion OF this Society,
to eloc drunkard, either to make laws, or, to ex-
ecue them, when made, s, virtually, not only to
legahze but to honor crime-to break down the bar
rier which Reason, Truth and Scripture have fixed
between virtue and vice--and to lay the axe at the
very root Of the Tree Of Liberty.


3. Resolved, That in the estimation Of this SocIe-
ty, the employment of drunken servant-a drum
ken mechanc--a drunken schoolmaster or an in
temperate physician, without necessity. and merely
because such may be obtained, upon cheaper terms
than such as are sober and Industrious, is to crafty
avarice at the expense of moral principles to ex-
ercse and indulge narrow, selfish disposition, in
the place of that heaven-horn benevolence which
consults the good ofthe 70holc community.


A. Resolved, That, we esteem it good rule and
worthy Of universal observance. for every minister,
when called to preach funeral sermon to let it be
distinctly understood. as condition. that no splrtu-
Gus liquor be used on the occasion.


5. ResolUcd That il be recommended to the fe-
male part of the community to dscountenance and
| frown from their social circles all young men who
are frequently known to be in state of intoxlca-


ton, and to look aYitt suspicion upon such as tona
of strong drink.


6. Resolyed. That we view, with the deepest re-
Gret, the erroneous conduct of those parents who
train up their children to the regular, habtuaI uee
of strong drink The wisest OF men hath said !;
g Train up child in the way he should go, and when
he is old he will not depart from it." IT tins be
true as general rule when children are trained 10
sobriety, industry and piety how much more may
those parents who train up their children, by pre-
cept and example, to believe, that the habtual use
of strong drink s essential to their health and COM
fort expect that the habit uiH become second ma
t,.re that the chains put on, in infancy, and worn
with ease and without suspicion, to manhood VIII,
in old age if not before, bind the victims to iniamy
and death.
RI T. Resolved, That we recommend to all gonng
ministers, who desire that their instructions and
warnings against the sin of drunkenness may have
the desired effect, to abstain altogether from the
use of spurious liquors.

uhia National Gazette furnishes the following no.
tice of the present condition of this Canal The
three sections through the marshes from the Deia-
ware river to ST. Georges about four miles in length.
are filled with water nearly as high MS the common
high water of the river, and an active navigation
along it in sloops and scows for the purposes of the
Canal is carried on ; dredging machine is employ
ed in excavating such parts as arc not to the full
depth of ten feet the towing path embankment
Through the marsh has ceased to sink, and appears
TO stand perfectly firm; the south guard bank, OF
which the sinking was so rapid and extensive, and
